intro: Papaver pollakii, commonly known as the Pollak's poppy, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It is characterized by its striking, cup-shaped flowers that range in color from deep red to orange, depending on the variety. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and has hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves. It thrives in well-drained soil and full sun, making it a popular choice for rock gardens and alpine settings. The flowers bloom in late spring to early summer, adding a vibrant splash of color to its natural habitat.
